31656451.review:
Westerado: Double Barreled (WDB) è una piacevolissima sorpresa. L'aspetto blocky di una pixel art volutamente lontana dalla perfezione cela in realtà un gioco più profondo di quanto possiamo immaginare, che coniuga meccaniche shooter con un'esplorazione open-world - il tutto rimanendo fedele ad una filosofia indie come sempre votata a produrre titoli semplici ed altamente giocabili.

Il gioco ci vede nei panni del figlio minore di una famiglia di allevatori nel vecchio, selvaggio West. Un giorno ci allontaniamo da casa sulle tracce di un bufalo fuggito dal nostro ranch, e al nostro ritorno ritroviamo la fattoria in fiamme, nostra madre accasciata a terra senza vita e nostro fratello ferito a morte. Prima di passare a miglior vita, con le ultime forze il ragazzo ci fornirà un indizio sul misterioso assassino: a questo punto inizierà una caccia senza sosta che ci porterà a viaggiare in lungo e in largo per trovare indizi che ci avvicineranno a lui, per cercare di placare infine la nostra sete di vendetta.

WDB è in sostanza un piccolo, minuscolo sandbox in cui potremo esplorare liberamente le zone circostanti interagendo in (relativa) libertà con gli individui in cui ci imbatteremo. Sia chiaro, non stiamo paragonando Westerado agli ultimi GTA, Fallout o Far Cry: le zone esplorabili non sono enormi, e i viaggi da un punto all'altro della mappa durerano al massimo un minuto o poco più (molto di meno se utilizzermeno il cavallo). Tuttavia rimane l'inconfondibile piacere dell'esplorazione libera, e il gran numero di missioni diverse che potremo intraprendere renderanno l'avventura sempre appagante e mai banale.

Lo scopo del gioco nelle sue fasi iniziali sarà quello di viaggiare fino alla vicina città di Clintville per parlare con lo sceriffo dell'assalto avvenuto e cercare di raccogliere ulteriori indizi sull'assassino della nostra famiglia. La città brulica di persone, e tra queste troveremo diversi NPC disposti ad affidarci missioni di diverso tipo in cambio di informazioni preziose per la nostra caccia all'uomo. Una volta completata una missione otterremo un'indicazione sull'abbigliamento del fuorilegge: piano piano i tratti distintivi della sua figura si faranno sempre più chiari e definiti - ad esempio un cappello largo, una cintura con borchia argentea, la bandana colorata, ecc. - e questo ci permetterà di individuarlo in mezzo alla gente e smascherarlo.

La bellezza di questa meccanica, che mi ha subito riportato alla mente le partite ad Indovina Chi? di qualche decennio fa in compagnia dei compagni di scuola, è che ad ogni partita l'aspetto dell'assassino viene generato randomicamente, rendendo di fatto ogni run diversa dalla precedente. La rigiocabilità è un aspetto essenziale di WDB: le partite difficilmente dureranno più di un paio d'ore, e con tutta probabilità non avrete bisogno di completare TUTTE le missioni secondarie per riuscirete a identificare il colpevole. Con un playthrough successivo potremo quindi seguire una o più questline che non avevate intrapreso nel precedente (per scelta o per necessità, visto che alcune sono mutuamente esclusive), aumentando decisamente la longevità generale del titolo.

Ho parlato fino ad ora delle meccaniche generali... ma che gioco western sarebbe se non avessimo a disposizione un arsenale di tutto rispetto per farci strada a suono di piombo tra banditi e fuorilegge? Su questo fronte WDB ci propone una selezione di armi standard da cowboy, tra cui potremo trovare revolver (la nostra arma di partenza), fucili, carabine e persino bolas e tomahawk, ciascuna con caratteristiche e pregi/difetti differenti. Tutte le armi condivideranno la modalità di utilizzo: sarà infatti necessario dapprima estrarre l'arma, e in seguito caricare e fare fuoco - il tutto tenendo sempre d'occhio il caricatore, per evitare di trovarsi senza proiettili nei momenti più "caldi" del confronto. 

Potendo far fuoco solo orizzontalmente bisognerà fare molta attenzione ai movimenti di avvicinamento dei nemici - passatemi il paragone azzardato, è un po' come nei vecchi Golden Axe/Doubel Dragon, in cui le sovrapposizioni coi nemici e gli avvicinamenti richiedevano molta attenzione. La barra vitale è sostituita in WDB da una serie di tre "cappelli", acquistabili in città negli appositi store o recuperabili dai nemici morti: ogni colpo subito ci farà perdere un cappello e, una volta rimasti senza, ogni singolo priettile potrà spedirci al creatore. 

Dal punto di vista grafico, il gioco è completamente bidimensionale con visule isometrica ed una pixel art che riesce a soddisfare pur senza esibire un livello di dettagli particolarmente fine: anzi, durante le conversazioni con gli NPC la scena verrà zoomata e potremo apprezzare in tutto il loro splendore i macroblocchi di pixel che compongono le figure. E' una direzione artistica diametralmente opposta al trend degli indie attuali che cercano la perfezione nei songoli pixel di ogni sprite, ma non si può certo dire che il risultato finale non sia piacevole. Altrettanto godibili sono le tracce audio country, in cui l'armonica si prende il giusto ruolo di protagonista: il materiale è tutto molto orecchiabile e perfettamente centrato rispetto all'ambientazione generale.

Dunque, ricapitoliamo. Siete amanti della grafica retrò e sapete chiudere un occhio davanti a blocchi cubitali di pixel? Non disdegnate un po' di esplorazione e sentite il bisogno, di tanto in tanto, di una sana sparatoria? Siete cresciuti a pane e Sergio Leone e vi credete più fighi di Lee Van Cleef quando maneggiate una pistola? E allora cosa aspettate: correte ad installare WDB, sellate il cavallo, armate i revolver e lanciatevi subito alla ricerca di quel figlio di una grandissima putt...AHAHAHAHAAAAAAAAAAA WHA WHA WHAAAAAAAA.

31594958.review:
Until Red Dead Redemption comes to PC this is the best Western game I've played on PC!

Within the first few minutes of the game your family is murdered and you set out on a quest for revenge. Completing objectives, from gambling, returning a drunk husband to his wife to transporting buffalo and every western style thing in between nets you clues about your families murder. From the color of his belt buckle to whether he was thin or fat, you piece together bits about what he looks like so you can confront him. Or kill every single person if you want until you stumble upon him!

The graphics are very old school, taking the style of late 80s early 90s dos games. It reminds me a lot of the animation and graphical style of Delphine Software games like Out of This World. The animation in particular is wonderful. Areas are alive with motion, particularly from animals like birds that take flight as you wander the wild west.

Soundtrack is also great, from saloon pianos to wonderfully atmospheric music as you trek the deserts and forrests.

One thing though is that the game is not particularly long. My first playthrough took around three and a half hours to avenge the death of mah family. The good news? Game is incredibly replayable. Your family's killer is randomized and there are multiple endings based on your behavior through the game. There are also multiple factions that give you freedom in how you deal with them. For example, the army and indians are in conflict. You may never even approach the situation, side with either group OR find a peaceful solution to the conflict!

31579673.review:
[h1][b]■どんなゲーム？[/b][/h1]

アクション要素のあるアドベンチャー。
母親と兄の仇を取るために町の人の頼まれ事を聞いていく。
クエストをクリアすると犯人の外見の特徴の一部を教えてもらえるので、その情報をもとに仇を探す。
犯人はランダムで町をうろついているので、怪しいやつがいたら「お前かー！」と凄んでやろう。

クリアするだけなら必須クエストはない。たぶんその辺の町で適当に銃ぶっぱなして馬で逃げていくやつがいたら追いかけるぐらいの適当なプレイでもクリアは可能なはず。

[h1][b]■割と周回前提[/b][/h1]

というわけでこのゲームのプレイ時間の大半はクエストをこなすことに費やされるが、これが結構分岐が多い。
特に対立する勢力のどちらにつくかという選択が多く、1周では全てを回収することができないようになっている。

また、犯人の正体もこなしたクエストやプレイ状況などで分岐する。
どのパターンでも割と衝撃の事実が発覚するので結構面白い。

[h1][b]■アクションは易しめ[/b][/h1]

基本的に攻撃するときはy軸を合わせて撃って相手が構えているときにはy軸をずらせばいいだけなのでそれほど難しくはないと思う。
大体の場面ではマップ切り替えで仕切り直しも可能。

[h1][b]■世界観など[/b][/h1]

どこか寂しい雰囲気のBGMと彩度の高く鮮やかなドット絵の中で西部劇の世界を堪能できる。
ここにはインディアンがおり、それを討伐しようとする軍もいる。
私欲にまみれた石油王とそれに従うならず者がおり、その所業に苦しめられる地主がいる。
どちらの側につこうと自由だし、面倒ならどちらも皆殺しにすることだってできる。
何せこのゲーム、家族の復讐を目的にしておきながら生き残った肉親にさえ鉛弾を食らわせることができるのだ。
脳内RPを楽しめる人なら、その行動の幅を楽しむことができると思う。

[h1][b]■総評[/b][/h1]

先に欠点を挙げると、1周が短めなせいかイベントの密度や量については少し不満が残る。
また、取り返しのつかない選択が多い割にオートセーブなので、イベント回収プレイの際にやや不便に感じる。
一応プレイアブルキャラが複数いたり、単発のクエストにも細かい分岐があったりと周回を飽きさせない工夫は感じるので、何周もすることを許容できれば大丈夫だと思う。

プレイ体験の質については概ね満足。セールで買ったけど定価分まで投げ銭したいぐらい。
（Steamでそういう機能実装してくれませんかね？　それとも私があるの知らんだけ？）

31465550.review:
Wobec Westerado: Double Barreled nie miałem żadnych oczekiwań. Kupiłem ją na przecenie z dwiema innymi produkcjami i nie wiedziałemczego się w ogóle po niej spodziewać. Jednak po ukończeniu tej indie perełki mogę stwierdzić że to jedna z fajniejszych gier jakie ostatnio skończyłem. Wcielamy się w tajemniczego rewolwerowca i naszym zadaniem jest pomszczenie naszej rodziny. Cała gra opiera się na znalezieniu mordercy. Wykonując questy (które można zrobić często na kilka sposobów) otrzymujemy wskazówki na temat poszukiwanego. Możemy zebrać wszystkie poszlaki i żeby dokładnie wiedzieć jak on wygląda, ale równie dobrze możemy zebrać np. tylko połowę i spróbawać zgadywać. Można także po prostu zabić wszystkich po kolei z nadzieją że trafimy na mordercę, ale trzeba pamiętać NPC nie odradzają się. Gra ma sympatyczną mechanikę strzelania, fajne dialogi i wylewającą się z ekranu atmosferę dzikiego zachodu. Dodając do tego przyjemną, pixel-artową grafikę i klimatyczną muzykę nie sposób nie polecić Westerado.

8/10 ŚWIETNA

31379379.review:
Westerado is a unique gem. Its an open world action/adventure with a lot of comedy but with plenty of great mechanics to back it up. Case in point: your health is measured in hats and if you are able to shoot the hat off your oponent then you can pick it up for +1 health. Also to use your gun you need to unholster it, cock the hammer, and pull the trigger, this takes three different button pressess which sounds weird on paper but is really satisfying. 

The game world is a bit small compared to other games but offers replayability. You are free to explore as wish and can pull out your gun and shoot anybody at any time. But this is the old west and your choices have consequences so there are plenty of folk who will take out their guns and see fit to fire back. Moreover charecters that are intergral to quests can die and cause you to fail that quest. 

The main goal is to find the man that burned your ranch and murdered your family. The reaseons for why he did it change every game and offer storyline replayability. There are other playable charecters you can unlock with differing gameplay. You can even choose a hardcore mode with permadeath. I think westerado is a great game that everybody should try.

31338304.review: This game saves at its own discretion. If you as the player cannot decide where to save your game but have to go to specific checkpoint to save, then I would not be so mad. But when a game gets to decide not only the place but also the "time" to save your game, and not letting you know whether your progress was saved or not, I called it total garbage. If this game had let players save their game properly whenever and wherever they want like a good gun blazing action rpg that it is then I would really recommend it. When the game designer use a saving mechanism like this, the game just turned into un-playable piece of cr_p immediately. Why would game designers still use this kind of game saving mechanism nowadays? It is absolutely unacceptable. Who would want to close the game, and open it later to find that they have to do the last long mission again because the game saves progress like this?

31291503.review:
Just completed my first playthrough of Westerado. I really enjoyed myself and I learned how to play poker!

The combat is a little wierd at first because you can only fire your gun left or right. After getting used to it I found the cock and fire mechanism novel and challenging.

This game has Skyrimesque freedom. The map feels relatively large given the length of a single playthrough(I took about 4 hours). There are a ton of different areas and more quests than you're likely to complete in a single play through. There's a fairly large section of the map I didn't visit at all. Story elements sometimes appear unexpectedly, but I've only played through once so I don't know if they repeat each time or if they're random. 

Gameplay is diverse. There are poker games you can join in the towns. Riding sections and gun fights on and off horseback. Characters are interesting and involved in complex shenanigans with each other. Quests all feel like little slices of life. 

There aren't any roleplaying elements per se but you can earn money, and reputation. You can customize your character's appearance and there are multiple characters and weapons as well as hats. 

I've never been particularly interested in the western genre, but I found this game to be a lot of fun and I'm looking forward to my next playthrough.

31262818.review:
Alright, after 3 hours I have finally finished this game and honestly, it was a nice experience.
It's a very nice casual game with it's challenges if you're not too familiar with the controls and way that combat works. There's definitely some skill that goes into it and the final fight for me took probably 5-6 tries.

Now as far as a list of pros and cons:

Pros:
Comfortable yet challenging combat.
Decent sized world with lots of people and side quests.
Absolutely wonderful for the price (I got it on sale).
Has a good variety as far as weapons go with a rifle, shotgun, dual pistols, and regular pistol. (Although shotgun can be OP)

Cons: 
Sometimes difficult to follow the quest you're on, really have to pay attention to the text.
Not really much consequence for death, pretty much just respawning.
NOT ENOUGH HATS/CLOTHES

Overall I'd give the game a nice 8/10 for the fact it's a clearly indie game that did a good job and kept me hooked for awhile. Still need to test the replayibility but with every playthrough changing who your final enemy is I'm sure it has a decent level to it. Good for casual gaming sessions on the go.

31246173.review:
Hillarious, action packed, and just plain fun.

The game isn't too long (it took me only a few hours to beat) but was still quite enjoyable. Has a pretty engaging story for what it is, presents a good challenge that isn't too frustrating and has a great western theme. Not only that, but this game actually has a pretty funny/interesting easter eggs (go on a civilian killing spree to find one and have a real challenge). 

The gun play is quite smooth and the controls are good. The game is very responsive and has a great sound track. The gameplay is mostly running around dodging bullets and shooting at bandits, basically what you would expect in a western/cowboy game.

The story is a sort of mystery/whuodunit type thing that changes after each play through. The game is open world, which is very nice. You are free to go as you please, as long as you can blast your way through if need be. Also be careful, as dead people stay dead! Don't kill the shop keeper if you want to keep shopping. As you progress, you unlock new clues as to the appearance of who the killer is. It makes it exciting to get to each chapter as you keep a lookout for the culprit.

With all that said, I do think this game is a little expensive. I personally only plated through once and a bit and spent the rest of the time running around on a rampage, which was still satisfying. Unless you think you can get through multiple times without getting bored, wait until its on sale. At the time im writing this, its at 80% off, which at that point I think it's a must buy. At 50% off I'd still recommend. For what it is, I'd put this game in the range of 8/10.

31244846.review:
The original was pretty good, but it was windowed and your progress seldom saved...
But [i]this?[/i] This was amazing!
The gameplay was responsive and intuitive, and the pixel graphic artstyle was very well executed!
     Although the problems I have listed underneath are [u]very[/u] nitpicky, most of them have also been recognised by the very responsive development team as well and are being worked on for future updates:
[list]
[*]Sometimes the weapons that you buy do not appear in your inventory, and you have to buy another weapon and then switch them out. Its only minor, but it did mean that i had to buy more weapons than I really needed for my playthrough.

[*]There's a little hat bug that makes it so your hats are the same as they were earlier, when you switch out your guns.

[*]After I failed to save Rancher Bob's ranch on my first playthrough, it was still burned down when I started a new save with the sister, which was a little weird...

[*]The guiding mechanic for the alive bounty missions for me is a little buggy, and sometimes they'll stop dead and never move again, even wih my gun pointed at their temple!

[/list]
Overall, the game achieves what it set out to do [b]magnificently[/b] well, not to mention the immersion of acting out everybody's dream of being in a 1980's western movie! there's even [spoiler]a hidden movie set in the game![/spoiler]. Although, I wish I hadn't seen it so early in my game, so I could carry on taking everything seriously without the nagging [spoiler]4th wall break[/spoiler] in the back of my mind. Not a fault of the Devs [i]at all[/i], it's just that I wished i'd seen it in, say, a second playthrough so I could [spoiler]continue to take everything seriously[/spoiler]. But again, it was all my fault, and it was really well hidden too, so kudos to them.

Tl;dr, fantastic game with intuitive design and gameplay that did what it set out to do [i]really well[/i].

31242709.review:
It's a simple game. It's a "fairly short" game. It's stupidly fun.

The controls are difficult to get the hang of initially, as you have to prime a gun's hammer before shooting (it is the old west afterall), but they actually make total sense and you quickly acclimatize to them. The game *can* be very simple if that's how you want to play it. You don't *have to* do all the side quests. You don't *have to* hunt down all the bandits with a price on their heads. It's completely optional to take every card player in the saloons to the cleaners by being a poker badass.

You don't even *have to* buy a gun; you can just use your starting revolver for the whole game, rush through some of the key questline to get a vague idea of who you're going after, and go around accusing people of murder until you trigger the end boss event.

However, unless it's for a *specific achievement*, if you play games like this then you're missing the point, and living a bleak, joyless shell of an existence.

Shoot some bandits, find some loot, buy a sweet pair of shooting irons, kill some more bad guys, win a few hands of poker and sleep with the sheriff's wife dammit!

And when you're done, replay it from the point of view of another character you've unlocked by being an old west badass!

31184429.review:
Probably the best western game on Steam right now. You play as a gunslinger who is hunting down his family's killer. You gather clues about your culprit's identity through a bunch of different (side-)quests. The murderer is different every playthrough, which makes this game highly replayable.

What makes this game unique is its surprisingly large open world, along with its interesting mechanics. You can pull your gun on anyone, including important NPCs, and this sometimes leads to unique dialogue. Everyone can die, too.

The combat-system is surprisingly intuitive, if a bit simple. You can carry up to three hats. These hats protect you from gunshots. If you get hit, you lose one. If you get hit when your hat-stash is depleted, it's game over, and you'll have to restart from the last checkpoint.

All in all, I highly recommend this game. It's worth it at full price, and a must-buy when it's on sale.

30507085.review:
웨스테라도 : 더블 배럴드는 서부개척시대를 소재로 한 게임이다. 애초에 플래시게임으로 무료로 공개되었던 이 게임은 올해 초에 몇가지 편의 기능을 더 추가해 스팀으로 발매되었는데, 황량한 황무지를 표현하면서도 무언가 발랄한 색감과 독특한 전투 시스템, 복수에다 추리를 끼얹은 이야기 진행, 오픈 월드를 채택해 전체 맵의 모든 지역을 제재 없이 이동할 수 있는 등 게이머들이 혹할만한 것을 많이 갖추었다. 레드 데드 리뎀션을 이렇게 만들었으면 좋았을 것이다라고 말할 정도면 뭐...

 위 요소들만 보면 웨스테라도는 학생 신분으로 만든 게임치고는 대박을 터트릴 수 있을 것처럼 보인다. 하지만 게임의 각 요소들을 모아놓고 한번 클리어한 뒤에 그 느낌을 표현하면 뭔가 애매하다. 일단 게임 시스템은 잘 갖추어져 있다. 플레이어는 맵 전체에 걸쳐 존재하는 NPC들과 대화를 나누면서 복수 대상에 대한 정보를 수집하게 되는데, 공짜는 없는 법이기 때문에 무언가를 해준 뒤에야 범인의 인상착의에 대한 정보를 '일부' 얻을 수 있다. NPC들이 주는 퀘스트를 해결할 때마다 정보를 조금씩 얻게 되며 그에 따라 복수 대상의 윤곽이 드러난다. 인상착의가 다 갖춰지면 복수 대상을 잡으러 가면 된다.

 게임에서의 재미는 복수 대상을 잡는 것 자체가 아니라 그 과정에서 생기며 실제로 처음 플레이해보면 퀘스트 몇 개를 하게 되면서 마을의 분위기에 취하고 무언가 대단한 일이 일어날 것이란 기대를 품게 만든다. 그러나 그 기대감은 시간이 지나면서 점점 사라지게 되는데, 그 이유는 각 퀘스트들이 NPC에게 영향을 끼치기도 하지만 주인공에게까지 연결되지 않기 때문이다. 퀘스트가 주인공과 NPC 간의 연대감 혹은 반감을 형성하는 게 아니라 그냥 복수 대상의 정보를 두고 거래하는 느낌이다. 어느 시점부터 자발적으로 세계나 분위기를 읽고 맞춰 행동하는 게 아니라,  '드래곤볼 8개를 찾아라' 식의 메인 퀘스트에 서브 퀘스트가 아무런 고민 없이 이어진 들었다. 결국 이런 생각을 하게 되면서부터 탐험하고 싶은 마음은 접게 되고 최대한 쉬운 퀘스트들을 해결해 범인의 인상착의를 밝혀내기 위해 노력하게 되며, 제작사가 만든 배경이라던지 세세한 설정들은 무효가 되어버린다.

 NPC들이 주는 부탁을 서브 퀘스트라 치면 메인 퀘스트인 복수 대상을 찾는 과정은 후반부에 시작되는데, 메인 퀘스트는 서브 퀘스트들과 연관이 전혀 없을 뿐만 아니라 아예 장소를 바꿔서 시작하고 그 이전에 일어났던 일을 다시 되돌아보지도, 되돌아가지도 않는다. 거의 끝 부분에 들어서면 이렇게 진행한 이유가 밝혀지는데 그것마저도 그럴듯한 알리바이를 대며 게임의 대미를 장식하는 게 아니라 게임에 실망한 이유를 변명하는 느낌이 든다.

 그래도 화사하면서도 서부시대의 요소를 반영한 그래픽과 나오는 등장인물들의 모습은 적어도 2시간 동안은 푹 빠지게 해줄 것이다. 서부의 그 로망을 반영한데다가 긴장감도 있는 총쏘기 방식이라던지 체력에 관한 표현은 정말 휼륭하고, 다양한 일도 일어나고 이야기 자체로만 보면 나름 반전도 있고... 전체 맵 중에 빈 공간이 너무 많던데 그 자리에 여러가지 세력을 더 추가하고 유명하거나 강력한 인물들을 많이 만들어서 그 중에 한명을 무작위로 선정했더라면, 거기에 그 진영까지 얽어서 이야기를 전개했다면 명작으로 남았을 것 같다.

30224576.review:
Best western game ever since Red Dead Redemption! 8.5/10! The devs did marvelously with what they had. The amount of content in this game is well worth the price tag. If you're familiar with the genre, you'll feel right at home, despite the 8 bit graphic and the humble length. I got this game after 1 year of release so I had the priviledge of playing the game in such a pristine condition. 

EVERY DECISION COUNTS! You'll see every fruit of our actions. If you like gun blazing with bandits, your infamous reputation will make them scare sh**less of you the next time they see you. And beware! ALL NPCS are KILLABLE! So you'd only have to blame yourself if you managed to blow up rancher Richard's head without hearing his proposal first. If you had a twitchy fingers, you might never know what you'd missed.

COOL MINIGAMES! Whether you want to deal cards at saloon or raiding caravans on the desert, Westerado has just the thing for you! But for the game this size, you have to balance quantity vs quality. I was left begging for more of the wild west thrill even after my 3rd playthrough. 

SIMPLE YET FUN COMBAT MECHANIC. You'll always be rewarded with good health if you're a good shot! Too bad most enemies only take 1 shot to take down. I wish there were more enemies like the final boss when you had to dodge, run and maneuver with your enemy because you couldn't just one shot him.

THE RIGHT ATMOSPHERE. The story is just a normal vendetta cliche, but the context and the atmosphere built around it is excellent! You can see all the struggles between Indians and the Army, between ranchers and the industrial powerouse, yet the approach is so casual and carefree that it's a welcoming change of pace after all the dark, gritty and mature western games we have out there. 

WANT TO SETTLE DOWN, BUY A RANCH AND PLAY SIM?......... Almost! You could get our own house though. And a trophy wife lol.

I understand this is a small scale indie game and it has offered me well enough for its price, but I cannot help but notice the potential of this game! It's capable to do much more than this! Keep up the good work devs! I'm looking forward to the sequel!

30133989.review:
Westerado: Double Barrelled looks, at first glance, like a cheapie indie game. The graphics are extremely primitive and blocky, and the game itself is extremely simple.

And yet, when you play it, you realize that some real love went into making it. Unfortunately, while this game has some real charm in its Western theming, and it certainly is clever in some ways, by the end of it I was left feeling as if it never really delivered.

But I’m getting ahead of myself.

Westerado is a pretty simple game – you move around in a top-down 2D fashion, you can talk to people and interact with (a very small number of objects) with A, you pull out your gun with the right shoulder button, you cock your gun and shoot it with right trigger (and you must cock your gun before firing it), and you reload with the left shoulder button. That’s it.

Where the game is interesting is that it is a mystery game – the central driving theme of the game is that your family was murdered and you, the Gunslinger, are going out into the desert to the nearby towns to collect clues. You’re given one random clue by your dying brother at the start of the game, and you must collect additional clues by talking to people – and, mostly, by completing various tasks on their behalf. The Native Americans want you to drive off the farmers and help them kill the soldiers and take over the nearby town. The Sheriff is depressed and needs to get back in the saddle, and his cowardice leaves you responsible for looking after the local people. The local railroad has had its tracks blocked off by some bandits, who are being paid off by the Banker, who in turn is in debt to the Oil Baron…

There’s a bunch of pretty standard Western tropes at play here, and the game plays with them, simultaneously poking fun at the tropes while simultaneously mostly playing them straight. For instance, your health is represented by hats, and when you get shot, your hat gets shot off – at which point you put on another hat. If you are shot when you are hatless, you die. You can buy new hats at the hatteries, which are definitely not at all suggestive of brothels, and you can also get hats by shooting them off the heads of enemies.

And yet, the game is often pretty serious – people can and do die, and you can even kill off main characters (or get them killed off when they follow you around on quests). Moreover, it is a revenge plot, as you try to track down your family’s murderer, and it plays that revenge plot quite straight – the murderer really is a terrible person, and when you gun them down at the end, your own homicidal tendencies are put under close examination.

The game has a lot of quests, and these quests, though short, are how you get most of your clues. Helping out various people with various deeds – some moral, some evil, some gray – helps you accumulate clues, and completing entire questlines with people will often reshape the world in some way.

The intent of the game’s multiple endings is to make these plots matter – if you follow a plot through to the end, the ending of the game will reveal that your family’s murder is related in some way to what you did during the game.

It also makes the game replayable – if you only complete enough quests to get enough clues to find the (randomized in appearance) murderer, who poses as one of the townsfolk in the towns, you can then play the game through again, do a different questline, and then track down the murderer again and get a different ending.

However, you can do a great deal of the content in a single playthrough, and this at times makes the game exhibit some odd bugs, such as the oil baron getting to take over a lot of land despite the fact that I never helped him, or a character making reference to some event they couldn’t have seen because they weren’t around at that location to observe it. This was kind of disappointing, and drew me out of the world in my first playthrough.

My other problem with this game is that, in the end, while the game’s simplicity is a virtue, it also didn’t really give the game much in the way of variety – ultimately, you just use your gun to shoot bad guys, and talk to people. The bad guys are all pretty samey in the end, with limited variety, and you have seen all that the game has to offer within the first hour or so of gameplay. And while the game itself is pretty short – and indeed, there’s an achievement for beating it within an hour, something which is eminently doable – after I beat it for the first time I wasn’t left feeling like I really needed or wanted to do so again.

This isn’t a terrible game, but it isn’t a very meaty one. If you appreciate very short games, and are willing to go after the murderer fairly swiftly, I suspect this may be okay for you; if you try to play this like a RPG where you try and complete all the sidequests before beating the final boss, I suspect you’re going to feel a bit disappointed.

30041046.review:
This game is fantastic. Absolutely fantastic. Despite its simple graphics, the game is visually stunning, with some backdrops looking intensely gorgeous. The dialogue is well written, the game mechanics are fascinating, and the story is simple, yet satisfying.
It's a simple revenge story, but with a hint of mystery thrown in. I won't spoil the ending, as you need to play it to fully understand this, but once it's finally over, it's overwhelmingly satisfying.
The freeroam aspect of this game is also great - you can kill pretty much whoever you want (with very few exceptions), do whatever you want, help whoever you want, fight whoever you want, and you can even play card games in one of the two saloons.
This game is also full of references and easter eggs, as well as another hidden little story about a certain group of bandits that doesn't affect the story, but adds another layer of depth to this game.
There are very few problems, but I guess I should mention them. The combat system can be a little annoying to new players, and it can sometimes seem a little unfair. However, once you've mastered the gunfighting system, it's pretty straightforward - draw weapon, cock weapon, shoot weapon, reload - and it does add a little more accuracy to this game (which to be fair isn't very outlandish to begin with).
Do I recommend this game? Yes. This game is absolutely fantastic, and definitely deserves to be played.

29512758.review:
One of my biggest gripes with the open world genre as of recent is how the main quest always seems to conflict with the idea of "do whatever you want, go wherever you want" that these games intend to transmit. "The world is under threat by an evil force and I am the only one who has the mcguffin to stop it, but im going to help this man find his goat first"
There always seems to exist a clash between the optional content and the main quest of these games, where the urgency of  the main storyline is brought to a hault so the player can do some side missions that in no way influence the outcome of the plot. This is not the always the case, but I do see some struggle in making a worthwhile and compelling story intertwined with sidequests, and even big games like Witcher 3 suffer from it, having a Hero's Journey narrative as the main quest when the optional content is so much more entertaining and interesting, and so removed from what you expect of the main storyline.
This isnt an easy thing to do, I can think of Morrowind and New Vegas as games that manage those aspects very well.

Well, I can now add Westerado to those games that balance the main quest with the optional ones.
In Westerado, your family is killed by a criminal, and your objetive is to find out who this guys is so you can kill him. Thats it. Simplistic I know, but it works wonders for how the game's quests revolve around that main goal.
You see, everytime you do a favor for someone in this world, they will give you a clue about how the bad guy looks, narrowing it down a-la Guess Who? boardgame.
This criminal is of course randomized, so the nature of the game is about replaying it so you can see the different outcomes of every storyline, because you essencially create it using the template the game provides you as a canvas.
Its such a simple thing, but it makes every single quest mean something to the main plot and giving you the choice of how you want to build that main plot since every quest can factor to the end goal.
Quests even intertwine with others, creating some surprising domino effects that increase the game's replayabilty. 

The game also has an hilarious mechanic where you can pull out your revolver mid conversation with NPCs and just shoot them if you are sick of hearing them. You can literally kill everyone and still reach the ending and in fact, the game lets you accuse anyone you find on the street from the get-go and you could actually find the criminal just by mere coincidence doing that. 
These simple yet inventive design choices for the game provide some quite hilarious and movie inspired scenes where you are pulling your gun at everyone, making false accusations and creating a quick bloodbath.

Now, im aware that this alone isnt gonna get Westerado all the awards for best storytelling or whatever, but I wish other games would be this creative about how they implement their narratives on games and I think this game is a great source of inspiration for it.
I really appreciate when games manage to merge gameplay and story in a meaningful way to the point you cant distinguish them, and I think you wont waste your time on this underappreciated gem.

As for the rest, you can already see it has very charming pixel art and cool Western aestethic, and the game doesnt shy away from showing from what movies it takes inspiration from. Good soundtrack and a great sense of humor.
This isnt a very long game so take that into consideration going into it, its all about replaying it .

Actual Review:

Westerado's a game where you go around shooting bandits and finding clues as to who slapped your ranch, mother, and brother with fire and bullets. Everything about the murderer is random; from his look, to his allegiances, hell, he can even be your pops. Now that's freaky.

The game world isn't too big, but it's fun to explore and filled with personality. However, the game can be incredibly short, especially when one character gives you a metric fuck ton of clues in one go. This is one game I wouldn't mind having some padding, frankly. Hell, each time I've played the game I've killed the murderer before I even bought a second revolver! Shame.

Since I wrote this review, I've unlocked the other two characters. Hero is totally standard. He starts off with 3 hats and a revolver, and can take 4 hits before death with full hats. Brother is different; he starts with a revolver AND dual revolvers (which I didn't even realize until I tried to buy the dual revolvers from the general store, that was embarassing) and he can't wear hats. He's basically the "What you thought this game was going to be when you bought it" character. Sister and Indian are basically different looking Hero-s with different weapons (Sister has a shotgun and revolver, Indian has like a tomahawk or something).

The combat is...unusual. You and enemies can only fire horizontally; no diagonals or verticals here. I can understand why they wouldn't let you shoot diagonally, but I feel like if they let you shoot vertically it could make the combat even better; then again, the final boss basically hinges on the fact that you can only shoot horizontally, so...yeah. The AI is decent enough, but it's really easy to trick them by camping near a transition...zone...thing...and killing them all there. I used this tactic a lot against groups simply because I found it amusing how they couldn't follow me out of their area. But if you actually fight in the zone the combat is much more tense and entertaining.

Also, if you kill enough bandits, those that are still alive will become absolutely terrified of you and won't shoot unless you do. It's a beautiful thing :,)

Oh, also, all the controls are on the keyboard.

tl;dr: westerado is fucking amazing and if you like twinstick shooters and rpgs you should totally play it

29239616.review:
O western definitivo dos video-games em 2D.

Eu nunca imaginei um jogo tão rico, tão livre em possibilidades, com uma história que apesar de simples, cativante, fosse me agradar TANTO de forma absurdamente rápida.

Westerado é um jogo de mundo aberto de ação com elementos de RPG que te deixa imerso no mundo western, e que consegue unir gêneros como "Faroeste épico", "Faroeste revisionista", "Faroeste clássico",  e "Faroeste spaghetti" em uma mídia só.

A trilha sonora é impecável, é imersiva por completo, que define o tom de aventura, exploração e vingança.
Os gráficos, apesar de pixelados, são extremamente bonitos, a estética é precisa e a ambientação é riquíssima, com desertos diferentes, montanhas, florestas e pouca água. Há também um detalhamento muito bacana na movimentação e em coisas simples, como ao recarregar a arma, você vê os cartuchos caindo do cano.

A jogabilidade é simples, mas extremamente funcional e divertida, e também é um jogo bem mais difícil que aparenta.
O jogo tem cutscenes em estética de película cinematográfica [literalmente] e você pode fazer escolhas tanto em diálogos, como nas missões. Há 5 finais que variam de acordo com algumas escolhas em específico.

A história é bem simples, mas é funcional, engajante e engraçada.
Não vi bugs.

Westerado: Double Barreled é para os video-games o que a trilogia dos dólares de Sérgio Leone é para o cinema.

Nota: 10/10

29177861.review:
Westerado: Double Barreled may not be the prettiest game around with its blocky pixel art, but what it lacks in the visuals department is made up with its gameplay and humor. It captures the feel of a good ol’ fashioned Wild West revenge flick while having a good, and sometimes really weird, sense of humor.

The fact that you can pull out your gun on anyone during any point in a conversation should tell you quite a bit about the tone of the game. The metaphor for physical intimacy also deserves a nod. You’ll run into weirdos, bandits, hat makers, bandits, people that can use your help, and more bandits. On your quest for revenge you can change the fate of some characters if you follow through on their questlines or just murder them in cold blood. 

All of the above means that there are different outcomes and methods to solving the same quest. For example, there’s a group of bandits blocking the railway with their shenanigans. You could murder them all, turn them into the sheriff’s deputies through a series of complicated steps, or even scare them away with a certain NPC. If you’re looking for an uncomplicated experience, murder tends to be a viable method of solving things, but know that it doesn’t have to be the only way. Making good dialogue choices might also accomplish the same task. Let’s not forget, you’re actively collecting clues to have a more complete picture of who the murderer is and the identity changes with every new game. Completing quests for NPCs rewards you with a single clue. You can also find the murderer by accident which I was able to do once. Let’s just say I forgot how to holster my pistol correctly.

Discovery is a big part of the game and the multiple endings add to that feeling. The kind of person you are is reflected in the ending and can be affected by siding yourself with important quest givers. If you’re achievement hunter, Westerado might have an even greater appeal to you since they generally have you going after different outcomes or scenarios that you might not have thought were possible. You can also have fun just by finishing the game a couple of times.

The gameplay is simple, responsive, and satisfying. You can shoot left or right and can move up or down. You have to pull back the hammer before you can fire and each round must be manually reloaded. This leads to some tense moments as you have to balance when to reload versus shooting back. Revolvers aren’t the only weapons, but they’re what I prefer. You can buy a shotgun, a rifle, or another revolver for some dual-wielding action.

Another great thing about the combat for Westerado is that enemies can harm each other. Maybe you don’t have a great window for reloading and there are enemies on both sides. Some nimble footwork can have enemies shooting at each other while you dance around. Most of the time, it happens accidentally, but doing it deliberately is also fun. Keep in mind that friendlies can unintentionally do the same thing to you and vice versa. Your lives are represented by the number of hats you have. You can have up to three hats to absorb shots; a man with no hat has a very short life expectancy. 

There are only a couple negative criticisms I can make. Sometimes alternate solutions to quests are just really complicated, even if you bust out a guide. If you mess up, you’ll need to start a new game. The fact that playthroughs can become very short once your familiarity with the game increases does soften the blow. The other aspect of the game I didn’t like were the really blocky characters. The environments looked fairly okay with the pixel art, but the people were just giant pixels to me. A few more details wouldn’t have hurt.

Other than those two things, I think Westerado is worth your time, especially if you’re a fan of the wild west setting. The fun gameplay, the silly things you can do, and the varied outcomes make this game pretty fun. Man, ah love my revolver.

27364051.review:
It's been described as Red Dead Redemption in 2D. And while I haven't played RDR (being a PC gamer) from what I know of Rockstar's open-world Western outing, it seems like an uncannily accurate comparison.

Westerado has simple mechanics: it's 2D, top-down, side-scrolling, and has just a few different weapons - but it's how it uses those mechanics that makes the game really shine. From the outset you can explore the open world as you wish, talking to anyone, killing anyone (if that's the way you like your Westerns), taking names and taking hats. The protagonist's accent is captured surprisingly well for text-based dialogue, and it adds that little extra charm to the game. 

There are warring factions in the West: the army, the Indians, the townsfolk, the oil tycoon. You can side with anyone and reap the consequences, or remain a lone gunman on his quest for vengeance. 

The music provides a huge part of the Western feel too, though it does eventually get a bit repetitive. 

There's also a good number of easter eggs and pop culture references, and the writing is just all-around light-humoured and entertaining to read.

A typical game from start to finish can last anywhere from 30 minutes to 10 hours or so depending on how thorough you are. This is a game designed for replayability: there are lots of things you can't do in a single playthrough due to the nature of choice and consequence.

In summary, a charming Western game that gives you a great amount of freedom to play as you like.

A single play through won't last you long (about 3 hours), but randomized murderers, multiple characters, and various secrets can provide a good amount of replayability. The gameplay itself is also quite good. The gunfights are quite fun, and can even be a bit tactical, at times. However, the conversation system and how you can interact with NPCs are the most interesting parts. In any conversation you can whip out your gun, with varying degrees of success, and you can just shoot everybody, if you want to. Overall, Westerado is a great game, that's totally worth your money.

27186976.review:
There are some games where you need to trust that it's going to be good and just not care about the negative reviews, this is one of those games. Every negative review harps on about how the gunplay is bad or that the game only lasts 2-3 hours, the gunplay is really a matter of opinion (I personally like it, and that seems to be the popular opinion) but the playtime argument isn't really valid. replayability is very high, you can fail almost every quest, and you'll have to figure out a new way to get hints as to who the murderer is. Playing one questline will often make another group/faction's questline inaccessible. So you can't play through all of the content in one playthrough, no matter what. What that means is, the playtime may be 2-3 hours, but that's only for your first playthrough. after that you'll be able to explore all the questlines you didn't get to play, and on the way to those you'll probably find an entirely new storyline you had never even seen. The game is jam packed with content, most of which requires exploring to find. 

You can beat the game only exploring around 25% of the map. Or in some cases, even finding the murderer by chance alone. The murderer is always walking around, so shooting random people is a legitimate strategy. You'll also unlock new characters to play as, allowing for challenge runs. The game also has a local co-op mode, though I never personally played it. The game is actually funny but doesn't go overboard on jokes, as to make it solely reliant on humor. You don't have to play through the same questlines over and over again for different playthroughs, the entire world is open from the start. So when you want to go back and find what other stuff you missed, you'll just be able to run to that location/look around for secrets.

The only complaint i can really issue is little, but towards the end game, so hover over if you don't mind spoiling some of the end game. [spoiler] The game has the same ending sequence each time you play, so every time you go to chase after the murderer, he will always get away and run to the end area. And it gets pretty boring going through the same thing over and over to see all the alternate endings, even though i can see the need for it.	[/spoiler]. Besides that, i really have no complaints. The game is very good and i would recommend it to anyone.

26595215.review:
I will list a few pros and cons I came across during my time with the game, to show what I observed and provide additional comments as I feel are necessary to explain.

Pros:
+ Horses you can use to fast travel
+ Extra "lives" (hats) from lining up shots just right, which helps balance out the deaths
+ There is a map, and a journal
+ Western-Style Murder Mystery (I'm not sure if the killer's identity is the same every time, or if it's like the Clue board game)
+ Quests
+ Go nuts murdering everyone in town; yes, almost everyone seems to have a gun, and killing them all is kinda relieving if you get frustrated with the game
+ Bank your money because if you run out of lives (hats), you lose half the money you have on you, which I think is pretty darn fair
+ Music was pretty nice


Cons (Adding spacing for clarity between each point): 

- Tons of NPCs to talk to with repeating dialog, but you want/have to talk to every one or you might miss a clue or a quest

- No mouse support at all

- You have to press J to draw your weapon, then K to cLock it (can't say cLock without the L on Steam), then press K again to fire it, then press R to load each, singular bullet into your gun...that's right, emptying a gun with 6 bullets and refilling it takes 19 button presses, vs. the 7 or 8 it would take in almost any other game ever made

- Quest Overload (all at once), ala the original Mass Effect Citadel, the beginning of Morrowind, etc., where you have a large number of quests piled onto you in a very short time, rather than a small, controllable trickle of quests that keeps you wanting more; especially ugly and overwhelming when done early-game, as with Westerado

- Failing quests that cannot be repeated due to derpy AI: I was sent to find a man in a mine, and when I got there, I found out I needed a light, so I had to talk to an old miner in town (had to find him which took a couple of minutes to begin with), who then he tells me he wants a 25-year-old train ticket. Fine. So I go to the train station and get that, bring it back to him, he give's me a miner helmet, then I die while going through the mine, losing the helmet so I have to wing it in darkness. When I finally get the guy, some jerks start shooting at me, and while I'm shooting back at them, the guy I'm trying to guide out of the mine for my quest runs like a chicken with his head cut off, right into the line of my gunfire, getting himself killed, which basically means I wasted about 25 minutes of my time on a quest that failed in one instant of the AI suiciding

- Pop culture jokes: I used to love this stuff, but I don't need to see Game of Thrones jokes (yes, I saw one in this game) in my western game I'm trying to get into

- Non-human enemies such as wolves can be a pain to kill, simply because lining up shots the way this game's combat works is pretty challenging. I shot three guys' hats off in a row, getting an achievement for that, but could not manage to shoot a wolf despite emptying my gun on it at different angles, trying to score a hit

- 8-bit graphics are old hat by now, and this game's combat system suffers for it. Blaster Master has more angles you can shoot at, and that came out in 1988. They could do so much better without having to go too much higher on a technical level.

- Lack of a main quest/motivation: Sure, the game gives you an end goal, but the game is sort of like "Hey, just do everything, and you'll get clues about who the killer is whom you're trying to find." In other words, you're encouraged to do every quest, without being told which quest(s) are necessary to complete the game. You will be running around just doing crap hoping it gets you closer to the end of the game, without really knowing if it does or not. This isn't particularly compelling or exciting.

-----Conclusion-----

Although there are some nice positives to this game, the negatives outweighed it for me, with the weird gunplay/combat mechanics that predate games from the late 80s, and the heap of quests the game throws on you without any indication of what's important and what's just busywork for suckers. A few decent features unfortunately do not make the overall experience of this game an enjoyable one for me, so I cannot recommend it.

26566040.review:
Before I start, I’ll just say that I remember playing this game on the Adult Swim website. It was a Flash-based game then but it was well made. As far as I understand, this is just an expanded version of that, so assuming it’s still available, you can go and enjoy it for a while before making a purchase.

I got [i]Westerado: Double Barreled[/i] from [i]Humble GEMS Bundle[/i], aptly named because it is exactly that ― a sweet little gem. It’s by no means huge, don’t take the talk about its open world to mean that this is one of those games where you can spend a hundred hours just wandering around and still not discover everything. Its size is instead rather fitting the 8-bit esthetics it carries. But still, there is plenty to discover, beautiful pixel graphics to enjoy, secrets and easter eggs to find ― and the game is partly randomized and possesses different paths you can take so that it really is a somewhat different experience every time. Overall, it took me 5 and ½ hours, according to the in-game timer, to complete it for the first time, discovering all of the map in the process (though not finishing all the quests). But you can also complete it in less than 30 minutes if you try to speedrun it.

I think that the relative, and apparent, simplicity of [i]Westerado[/i] is one of its greatest pluses. You know how sometimes video games draw you in with promises of an epic adventure or a deep story, and then it turns out that this gets completely compromised by the “gamey” mechanics? All of the big concepts get squished into the narrow constraints of a typical video game: a compass marker tells you where to go to complete your task, a named character means a quest giver, you’re presented with a “good” and an “evil” response during a conversation…

Well, what [i]Westerado[/i] does is kind of the opposite. You come in expecting a simple game where you shoot bad guys and collect bags marked “$$$”. You have hats which are tongue-in-cheek stand-ins for lives. You can also buy better weapons in the shop but don’t have to worry about ammunition, it’s infinite. Everything about the game, up to and including its graphics, tells you that it’s an arcade title, one that tests your dexterity for a while and then maybe assigns you a points score.

Only that it isn’t. What you will discover is a world full of characters whose fates you can indirectly decide. There’s never an obvious indication of the magnitude of your actions, you just do whatever feels right, and the consequences arise later. Don’t take me wrong, this game isn’t very serious and there aren’t huge moral quandaries. But what impressed me is complexity that arises organically from simplicity, rather than being forced from above and ultimately constrained. There is a kind of honesty that [i]Westerado[/i] has in comparison to most RPGs and the like.

There are, of course, bad sides to this game. The music is not terrible at all but there’s not a lot of it either ― I think only one track per area ― so you’re going to be listening to the same tune on repeat most of the time. Also, combat can be frustrating sometimes, weapons are not very well balanced, and there will be a new bug every couple of minutes. But overall, it’s hard not to recommend this delightful title, especially if you find it on a sale or something.

26506571.review:
Westerado: Double Barreled - Excelente - 10/10

1- O que você vai encontrar no jogo:

Um jogo de faroeste, com várias missões, mapas e finais alternativos. Gráfico pixelado, a jogabilidade realmente faz parecer que você está no faroeste.E uma música muito boa.

2 - O que dá para fazer

Comprar novas armas
comprar novas roupas
matar quase tudo que se move
explorar e encontrar surpresas (não vou dar spoiler)
Fazer missões

3- Sistema de batalha :

O seu estilo varia de acordo com a arma que usa, por exemplo a arma de tiro duplo.

Existe um botão para sacar a arma. Nesse momento, os npcs também sacam armas para se defender ou não.

O botão do tiro funciona da seguinte forma: se você clicar uma vez, ele engatilha a arma, só na segunda vez que atira.

Ou seja, para atirar é necessário : sacar arma + engatilhar e atirar. (se tiver bala na arma).

As balas são infinitas porém precisa recarregar quando a arma estiver vazia.

O jogo depende muito da movimentação, diferentemente de outros jogos do gênero como " A fistful of  gun", em Westerado você só atira para os lados, então os tiroteios são mais tranquilos, mesm enfrentando um elevado número de inimigos.
4- O sistema do chapéu

Neste jogo o personagem tem apenas uma vida, porém cada chapéu que ele carrega significa mais uma vida. Se você levar um tiro, perde um chapéu. Se levar um tiro sem chapéu vai morrer.

O mais interessante é que se você for bom de mira, pode tirar o chapéu dos inimigos e pegar pra você. Você só pode andar com 3 chapéus, mas pode trocar de chapéu com o que achar pegar do inimigo.


5- Conclusão

Eu adorei  o jogo, fiz apenas um dos finais. Jogaria novamente sem problema. Comprei no Humble Bundle, valeu cada centavo.Eu realmente indico este jogo.

Obrigado por ler esta análise.

Conheça meu canal no twitch

https://www.twitch.tv/faraquito

26477364.review:
Two word game description: Delightfully short.

Westerado is a retro-style, clue based game where your chief objective is to find the person who committed an autrocity to you and your family.

The controls for this game are simplistically intelligent and responsive. The art style is "cute" in a lovely, nostalgic kind of way. The music is appealing and not overbearing. Allegedly the game has lots of replayability as the culprit changes everytime, meaning you need to refind clues to identify who it is [as of 11/16 I have only completed one playthrough]. 

All-in-all this is a very fun game but not worth full price due to the short gameplay.

I would reccomend picking this up next time it's on sale.

Happy gaming!

26417388.review:
Westerado to prawdziwy sandbox i jeden z bardzo nielicznych przypadków, gdy miałem poczucie że moje działania w grze mają jakieś konsekwencje. Zastrzeliłeś kogoś? Trudno, nie żyje. Nieważne czy był to przeciwnik, przypadkowy przechodzień czy ktoś zlecający Ci zadania. Poczucie ostateczności takich decyzji wzmacia sposób, w jaki w grze rozwiązano obsługę broni. Nie wystarczy wskazać przeciwnika i kliknąć by pozbawić go życia: należy wyciągnąć broń (jeden klawisz, postaci odpowiednio reagują na taką akcję), odciągnąć kurek (kolejny klawisz, znów inna reakcja) i dopiero wtedy wystrzelić. Możliwość zrezygnowania w każdym momencie tego procesu dodatkowo wzmacnia uczucie, że kiedy pociągniemy za spust to klamka zapadła.

Nie zdradzając zbyt wiele: gra opowiada o poszukiwaniu pewnego człowieka i zemście. Wykonując zadania zlecane nam przez napotkane postacie zdobywamy kolejne wskazówki dotyczące wyglądu antagonisty: czy jego kapelusz jest wysoki czy też nie, jakiego koloru ma płaszcz a jakiego spodnie, czy nosi pas z dużą klamrą, jakiej jest postury itp. itd. Zadania są dość różnorodne: od eskortowania powozów (lub napadania na nie) przez chwytanie poszukiwanych bandytów po walkę (lub zawarcie sojuszu) z indianami. Oprócz wykonywania zadań możemy też zdobywać wskazówki na inne sposoby: choćby grając w karty w saloonach czy wypytując barmanów. Gra daje nam niemal całkowitą swobodę, w każdym momencie możemy zwiedzać dowolną część otwartego świata. W zależności od podejmowanych przez nas decyzji możemy potem zobaczyć jedno z kilku możliwych zakończeń (niektóre z nich odblokują możliwość gry innymi postaciami). W grze jest też sporo humoru i puszczania oka do klasycznych westernów.

Jeśli chodzi o rozgrywkę to Westerado możemy poruszać się naszym bohaterem w czterech kierunkach po dwuwymiarowych planszach. Strzelać możemy jedynie w prawo bądź w lewo, stąd walka opiera się na ciągłym pozostawaniu w ruchu i oddawaniu strzałów kiedy jesteśmy na tym samym "poziomie" co przeciwnik. W grze nie ma wskaźników typu HP czy licznik żyć - zastępują je kapelusze. Nasz bohater może w jednej chwili posiadać ich trzy sztuki. Każdy postrzał sprawia, że spada mu z głowy kapelusz. Jeśli dysponujemy zapasem, to zakładamy kolejny a jeśli przeciwnicy trafią nas kiedy mamy gołą głowę to kończy się to śmiercią. Domyślnie "śmierć" oznacza utratę połowy pieniędzy i powrót w określone miejsce na mapie, choć jest też do dyspozycji tryb ironman, w którym śmierć jest ostateczna.
Do dyspozycji mamy kilka rodzajów broni różniącej się zasięgiem i pojemnością magazynka. Poza przemierzaniem świata pieszo przyjdzie nam też kilkakrotnie walczyć z siodła. Poza eksploracją i walką będziemy również mieli możliwość prowadzić "dialog" z napotkanymi postaciami czy to wybierając z bardzo ograniczonych opcji dialogowych czy wykorzystując zastraszanie bronią. Da się również pograć w pięciokartowego pokera.

Podsumowując: gorąco polecam Westerado. Być może nie jest to gra jedyna w swoim rodzaju, ale ja nie spotkałem się jeszcze z sandboxem który jednocześnie oferowałby taką swobodę i nie był nudny. Dodatkowym atutem jest możliwość zagrania w prototyp tej gry w przeglądarce, za darmo.

Technical details:

Menu is not mouse driven. It is all controlled by keyboard. So that was a bit annoying.
Locked to 30 FPS. A little noticeable, doesn't affect gameplay too much.

The game:

I have not 100% completed the game. However, I have beaten it a couple of times. There is a lot of replayability here. Beyond the four characters, there are a ton of different ways to go about beating the game, from being a crazed killer to taking the moral route to being an outlaw to being a pacifist, etc. Beating the game can be done in less than an hour depending on how "experienced" you are with the game, but the first time through took me about 3 hours.

I had fun with it.

26403208.review:
I like it a lot! It has some problems stemming from basic design issues, but they're not impossible to look past. The idea is you're hunting down a criminal, but you don't know what he looks like and have to get hints from people to narrow down who it could be so you can confront and accuse them. This in practice boils down to doing sidequests and piecing together a picture of your culprit. Combat can be a little frustrating at first; you have to line up your shot, pull out your gun (without your gun you can only walk, not run), cock it, and shoot, each of which is a different button on your controller. In practice, combat boils down to getting right in your opponents line of fire and shooting them faster than they can shoot you. Shooting can only happen in two directions, so there's a lot of running around from all parties when a gunfight breaks out, and it feels like The Magnificent Seven (the new one, I haven't seen the old one), when all the cowboys are running and ducking about for cover before actually firing back.
A few of the quests are a little bit frustratingly ambiguous, but the world is small enough and your map is serviceable enough to help you find what you need to even when you're not given some sort of quest marker. 
My biggest gripe with the game has to be how much things break down a little when you've gained a reputation. After killing only a couple of bands of outlaws (or maybe it was specific outlaws, who knows) every random encounter I came across saw my enemies too scared to start a fight with me. That's a really cool feature, but made the last half of my game pretty uneventful altogether. That, and sometimes you can accidently aggro a faction and then encounter them later on in a place where being their enemies automatically fails a quest for you, without being able to undo that (this happened for me when I told the bullheads to work for a caravan company, and then before they left shot them all. I later encountered them at the caravan company, somehow still alive, but mad that I'd shot them all). This is find, that's how consequences work in open-world games with real consequences, but I can't help but feel like sometimes it was the result of slow event triggers or poor conveyance that I'd accomplished a task.

26372306.review:
TL;DR - An immersive, but clunky, pixellated top-down shooter in an Old Western setting, worthy of at least one playthrough lasting 1-3 hours. Recommend purchase during sale/discount.
 

Received the game via Humble Bundle purchase. Heard about the game and how it's a one-time playthrough kind of game. 

Starting the game, the visuals of the game are pixellated but with coloring to give you the sense of a western, desert environment. The music immerses you in an environment with various scenery and music to give a sense of cowboys and indians, ragtime in a saloon, and exploring mines. It very much feels as if you're involved in a time of the Old Wild West. 

With immersion aside, the gameplay mechanics did feel clunky and frustrating. Navigating the map was often as simple as following the notches on the edge of the squares on your map to new areas. Combat involved lining your character along a plane so that your weapon fires at the enemy. This plane of firing is only horizontal, meaning it's more beneficial to wait for your enemy to walk into your plane versus walking into your enemy's. Quest mechanics felt very frustrating as your "objective" in your quest log wasn't always specific and left you talking to vairous NPCs/roaming the map looking for a distinguished character that may have some new information. 

Both positive and negative considered, the game is defintely worth a pickup lasting 1-3 hours minimum for an initial playthrough, with further hours added for replayability in alternate endings, achievements, and easter eggs. I do not believe it is worth the current pricing of $14.99, but there are levels of polish with the music/visuals/side-quests that definitely make it worth the pick-up on a sale.

Dans ce jeu qui ne se prend pas au sérieux on incarne un cowboy qui devra venger la mort de sa famille et retrouver l'assassin (qui change à chaque partie) en enquêtant dans un monde ouvert fait de très gros pixels, de dialogues bien écrits, d'humour et d'action.

Westerado c'est aussi du fun, des pistolets qui se rechargent balle par balle, et qu'on doit armer avant de tirer (ce qu'on peut faire aussi pendant les dialogues !), des chapeaux qui font office de vies, et un petit côté RPG sympathique.
C'est enfin un gameplay 2D rétro plus malin qu'il n'y paraît, laissant la liberté au joueur de faire n'importe quoi (pas sans conséquences), et une bande originale d'excellente qualité.

Par contre Westerado c'est seulement 3-4h pour un run, ce qui fait court pour 15€ malgré sa rejouabilité.
Mais à 5€ par exemple (prix que j'ai payé, en promo) c'est une très bonne affaire que je vous recommande vivement !

26291750.review:
The game was absolutely fantastic. With all my love to pixel-art graphics at first I was a little bit sceptical while playing Westerado since the retro fascination was brought to a really high level here, but I eventually got used to this style. What's more, in the end i explored the whole map just to enjoy all music themes and graphical concepts.

I wouldn't say that Westerado could be a PC's Red Dead Redemption substitute for obvious reasons such as graphics or relatively simple plot. The main difference however is the fact that Westerado is far less complex and, at least for me, more relaxing than Rockstar's game. 

It is really brilliant how delevoper managed to combine the simplicity of a tiny indie game with the wide range of activities, locations and dialogues. What's more, your choices made during the whole game have their consequences in future and it is up to you how you will get to the final scene. That means that there is still much to come after finishing the plot for the first time.

And yet, for the whole time you still enjoy the feeling of playing a small, relaxing game.

The only thing that disapponted me though is the lack of New Game + feature. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to finish my sub-quests after getting to the end of the main story.

Anyway - wow. Just wow!

26246513.review:
I got this in the latest Humble Bundle, so I don't regret spending money to play it. In fact, the game does a lot of things right. It has a great art style, a bold and fitting soundtrack and what I liked most is it gives you a lot of freedom. Every character in the game as far as I can tell can be killed, which changes the game.

However, the most glaring issue is the combat. I'm not really sure why people are praising the gunplay in this game. It is simple but not in a good way. Overly simple to the point where aiming is just a chore. To fire your gun, you press J to unholster it, K to cock it and K again to fire. This is fine, but when you are given basically no idicator or reticle to where your shot will land it just ends up frustrating when you are certain you will hit someone and it misses. This could easily be fixed by simply adding a reticle to where your shot will land.

Omitting such an indicator isn't good design. It doesn't make the game harder in a way that is challenging yet fair. It's just annoying.

That said, if you can get past this, I would look at checking this game out for the aspects and mechanics it gets right. As I said, visually and audibly the game is fantasic. Both contribute to creating a world truly reminiscent of the wild west and to do so within the confines of a retro style is very impressive.

Character dialogue is also natural and written to match the theme well. No voice acting is present in the game, yet the dialect the characters speak in aid the western feel the game goes for, even if the "ah" in replacement for "I" can get tedious after a while.

I have only played under an hour, but I can only assume the hint system is in fact a system created to enchance the uniqueness of the game instead of just a way to advance the story. Furthermore the story is solid, albiet not wholly original. You play as a gunslinging rancher whos family are killed by bandit(s?) and you are set on your path of redemption.

Overall, this game just solidifies why the Steam thumbs up and down system isn't suitable. I'm in the middle. If you find the game on sale, try it, if not just to experience the world the game establishes. At just over £10 though I'm not sure the actual "game" part of Westerado is strong enough for a full price purchace.

在遇到SantaAnna女孩之前的大部分时间都是遇人不语就突突，带着一大笔钞票找寻到一家军武店，一个看店老头说他不管，他貌美如花（Lovely）的女儿是主事儿的。在店里找了一圈只有个卖帽子的傻姑娘，除了买帽子吗买帽子吗什么都不会说。
大概她闺女在外面大街上让我突突了。
我就把他和卖帽女也突突了。一家团聚。

整个游戏不能偷拿东西。军武店里的枪能看，也卖衣裳，老头是管服装销售的。突突了以后原来能买的花衣裳也不能选了。
早知道该杀前先整身时髦衣裳的。
硬派的西部牛仔能杀能抢不能偷。

对话系统比较有意思，可以说着说着忽然就掏枪吓他一跳。有回在城郊遇见一个独行的男青年，就跟他聊聊。然后忽然掏枪！他吓得不行，请把那玩意收起来。我就收起来了。他说感谢感谢么的么的。然后我又掏枪！他说你想干么么的么的。然后我就放下枪。然后我再掏枪！青年似乎崩溃了，喊了句JUST LEAVE ME ALONE!然后就跑。我就追，再掏枪！他再跑，我再追着掏枪。后来就跑不见了。以后再没遇到过。
不知道他若日后得知我是个曾连灭几城几寨的绝世恶徒会做何感想。

对了，除了地表世界外，还有个比较复杂的地下世界，应该都是挖矿地道，错综复杂。
阴暗的地下世界大概催生了邪教。。。。供奉着猫头鹰和蛇的巨型塑像，还有个挺大的仪式场。。。。具体是啥没具体调查，能说话的都被我突突了。

东区往东有个小别墅，封着门，挂着牌子说待售，可在银行购买。
各位守法少年如果在西部发达了可以试着看看能不能买得到。
我是白搭了，掖着全世界的钱，但是银行职员们好像被我早年间突突没了。

总而言之呢，渐渐对这个游戏产生感情了。没买房是遗憾，不该突突那么一些，该控制下出手次数的。跟人聊天其实挺有意思的，会有很多意想不到的对话和情况。
至于恶徒退隐之后嘛，就和花帽女孩呆在Santa Anna吧，说说情话，逛逛街，混迹沙龙，听人发发牢骚，偶尔去城北买顶帽子，洗却曾经的血雨腥风，平平淡淡过完余生吧。什么，你说线性任务？都突突了任务个毛。

好了，至于你们，我的朋友，新至西部的牛仔们，西部的世界很精彩的，请做好选择，但也要敢爱敢恨。


=========================================================
                                 以下是原测评内容
=========================================================

硬派 ，纯英文带俚语略吃力。
前期主线似乎是在男主他叔（还是他舅？）帮助下调查杀母真凶，他叔让我去村里做好事来赢得信任开展调查。
还没来得及开展调查，图新鲜在村里空地放了一枪，然后几个村民就拔枪绕着我乱跑要干我。
哪受得了这气，就屠村了。顺手把治安官杀了。
游戏提醒死的这位是任务NPC,...
原来游戏里任务NPC是能杀掉的啊...
后来莫名其妙涌出一大片警察，杀了来，来了杀，杀了源源不断来，就死掉了。
一段英文后复活，大概就是说有人救了我，然后顺走了我身上一半的钱。
复活后很着急的骑上小马去看治安官，嗯，都死透了。
原来任务NPC真的能被杀掉线啊..
然后就重复进行屠村-被莫名其妙涌出的众警察击毙-复活再去屠村循环中度过了一个来小时吧...乐此不疲...反正也没人引导该干啥去...
后来往北去了一片沙漠么的地方，让狼还有会遁地的蝎子整回了城。
后来杀了狼进了个山洞，把一群土匪突突死了，也可能是把矿里的一伙子守法矿工突突了。

续命系统很新风，打掉别人帽子捡起来就得一条命。
看对话这似乎是个常识。我跟他叔哭诉她妈和他哥惨遭杀害的时候，他叔就怪没戴帽子。
总之，帽子=多条命。


复活地是他叔家炕上。最后一次死返复活后出门左转把他叔也突突了。
他叔不死。
也没活。
居然变幽灵了。
我就跟他叔的幽灵聊天，他叔还特热情招呼我HOWDY NEPHEW!AH HOPE YA CATCH THE MURDERER SOON!CAN I HELP YA IN ANY WAY?也没提杀他这事儿，就一个劲关心男主他妈的案情咋样了男主过得好不好会不会开枪么的。
他叔要么有故事，要么脑子不大好。


游戏挺有意思的。
硬派。
聊啥天，做啥任务，浪费时间浪费时间，就突突。

26175600.review:
I love these kind of RPGish open-world indie action games with lots of characters to talk to throughout detailed pixel-art environments. The missions were a lot of fun to complete at your own pace while working toward the overarching story. This game would have been perfect except for two issues that really bothered me: 1) you can't redo failed quests, and the worst being 2) combat is generally kinda wonky. 

The combat really frustrated me because it was terrible compared to the rest of the game. Movement in general is kind of weird since it feels like you're a rook on a chess board. And then to add to the awkwardness of combat, you can only point your gun left or right while facing either direction. If someone is above you, you need to run upward and get him to your left or right side lined up since you can only shoot against that axis. You also can't run and shoot at the same time, needing to redrawn your gun. I died a bunch of times because of how awkward the controls feel - and dying isn't cheap since I kept getting robbed while unconscious. 

I'm upset they made such a great western game but couldn't figure out how to implement simple shooting mechanics.

这游戏叫一言不合就拔枪。
话说找sheriff的时候不小心拔了枪然后又不小心掉了一个帽子然后又不小心搞掉了NPC
报什么仇，先在酒店玩一局昆特…诶跳戏了。重开档吧。
满屏幕的像素小人都让我有突突的欲望，“伙计你帽子很好看啊，伙计你有好多道勒斯啊..人呐就都不知道，自己不可以预料。
玩了才一个小时莫名其妙找到了murderer，boss说追我啊追到我就让你嘿嘿嘿。接下来就各种死各种重生。话说我也是身经百战见的多了，西方游戏里哪一个boss我没有打过，我和他们谈笑风生。可是打boss还是被恶心到了。为什么好人都没有队友而坏人都特么一窝小弟（还和老大穿一样的衣服，基情满满）。
最后终于在一个小山坡上，boss用三条命演示了三种武器（尼玛这里要说一句，想好用什么武器再把武器店老板一家给突突突了，特么到最后硬是用远程步枪通了关，各种被冲脸。喷子才是王道啊，praise the sun！）
“额你打败我了小伙子，老夫纵横一生，没想到。。。
Draw the weapon
”我罪有应得，给我一个痛快吧。。
Bang！
然后就愉快地通关了（神他妈一个半小时通关）。
可是！！！
为什么没法二周目！！
开局后直接就跳到了上上个存档点，boss还在山坡上撒尿
我知道这就是你我的命运了。那么你活着也好。你只是一个NPC，而我是游戏的主角。
夕阳下，我看着boss不解的表情，骑上马离开了Hideout。
我回到了镇子上，血色残阳下，我把西部正义玩成了西部世界。这时回头看看boss的打扮，和我出人意料地相似。可能若干年后，当我再次无情地灭掉了一个家族时，也会有一个年轻人找我复仇吧。
那时我也会说出“给我一个痛快吧",然后看着他想象有朝一日他也像我一样，成为了嗜血的恶徒。

25956093.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

Westerado: Double Barreled is a top-down, open world Western shooter from the developers Ostrich Banditos and publisher Adult Swim Games, the game is an improvement from the browser gameof the same name; Westerado

Your family have been brutally murdered and your ranch has been burnt down, there is nothing left for you in this world, apart from revenge

In Westerado: Double Barreled you must complete jobs for people and in return for doing these jobs you'll be given clues about the appearance of the man who you seek to kill, alternatively you can go around shooting every last person in the hopes that one of them is the man you seek

The game has a gorgeous pixel art style and a reasonably big map which you can explore whenever you want to. There are lots of side quests to find and complete all of which have interesting stories to uncover and it captures the feel of the Wild West excellently

The writing is done phonetically for a Southern drawl which helps make it feel more real and the writing itself is fantastic and has simple, fun and often intense gunplay. A few different weapons to play around with: Revolver, Rifle, Shotgun, Dual Revolvers and Bolas

The game offers multiple endings and a few characters which can be unlocked. The game offers an excellent soundtrack and great sound effects. There are several factions/gangs within the game with poker mini-games and bounties which can be completed for money, however, the main quests can be completed very quickly though as mentioned there are plenty of side quests to do

Sadly, the game world is the same every time you play and areas aren't repopulated after everyone in said area is killed so there's no reason to revisit areas you've already passed through and the amount of money you lose when you die is too high in my opinion

However, an excellent open world Western shooter with gorgeous pixel graphics, a big open world, fantastic writing and intense gunplay. If you're a fan of Westerns then you definitely need to pick this game up!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

24949716.review:
This is really an impressive little game. First of all, it's probably one of the few pixel indies I've played that could actually be called "open world." Secondly, it's not open world in the Ubisoft sense where you run around collecting junk to check off markers on a map - it's actually got divergent paths that can make playthroughs radically different. 

For example, on my first playthrough:
* I didn't really know what I was doing and accidentally shot the gun store owner.
* Since I was now barred from buying new weapons, all the bandits in the desert kicked my ass and kept me from exploring more than 50% of the map.
* I totally botched a raid on the oil tycoon's house because my firepower wasn't good enough.
* I tried to get with this lady in a red dress who seemed interested in me, but because I had shot a bunch of guys at the oil tycoon's crib, they kept coming at me for revenge when I neared the premises. Thus, I wasn't able to talk to the red lady in that particular location and complete the quest line.
* Despite all this, I still managed to beat the game thanks to the train conductor, who gave me info on the guy who burned down my ranch after I bribed the thugs who had set up shop on the rail tracks. 

On my second playthrough:
* Instead of shooting the gun store owner, I carefully purchased a fine pair of dual wielding pistols.
* Blessed with double the gunpowder, I mowed down all those bandits preventing me from exploring the mines.
* I successfully brokered peace between the Native Americans and the white folks, thanks to the fact that I could now make it through the mines to explore the forest on the other side of the map.
* I cleared the train tracks again and reunited with my sister, who came to visit me from the big city! Together we helped fix a town's water supply. 
* I was able to complete the quest line with the lady in the red dress, but because I had killed so many dudes in the desert with my two pistols, she said I was too violent and she had really just been using me for sex. I got mad and shot her. 
* I still botched the raid on the oil tycoon's house, and he ended up killing all of my fellow rancher friends, but I got revenge this time and blasted him away in his office once I'd dispatched the goons at the front door.
* Finally, when I reached the end boss, he revealed that the aforementioned fellow ranchers had *gasp* actually been setting me up the whole time, and had hired him to burn down my family's ranch to lessen the competition!  

There's still enough stuff left in Westerado to make third and fourth playthroughs worth my while. I've unlocked the ability to play as my sister and brother and I want to try allying WITH the oil tycoon instead of unsuccessfully raiding his house over and over again. So yah, this game is impressive! I think it's actually made me like Western settings more. Check it out if your favorite movie is The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, or at least try the free Adult Swim browser version.

24026965.review:
They distilled a massive open world game down into a compact and fun indie title.  

It's completely non-linear, except for the finale.  There's lots of places to explore, different quest lines, different ways to accomplish each quest, different results in the world from your choices, and none of them are required.  At any point in a conversation you can draw and cock your weapon for different results, although it's not used as much as it could be.  If you want to, you can kill anybody and everybody.  The art is good and the music is fantastic.  The writing is great, with a lot of humour.  Combat is probably the weakest part of the game, and can be a little clunky.  You only shoot left or right so a lot of combat is running up/down, drawing, cocking, and shooting.

Beating the game for the first time takes 1-2 sittings, depending on how much you explore.  The bulk of the gameplay is in replaying to follow different quest lines, take different sides of conflicts, and see things that you missed.

Overall it's a delightful and enjoyable game that will stick around for me as something fun and light to replay for a quick hour.
